description: From Italian giannizzaro, possibly via French janissaire or Spanish jenízaro, from Ottoman Turkish یڭیچری‎ (yeniçeri), from یڭی‎ (yeni, “new”) + چری‎ (çeri, “soldier”). Compare Dutch janitsaar, German Janitschar.  The word is attested from the early 16th century in English; the janissaries themselves date from the 14th century.

entries.meaning: (historical) An infantry soldier, often of Christian descent and forcibly converted to Islam, in a former elite Turkish (Ottoman) guard (disbanded in 1826); (by extension) any Turkish soldier, particularly one escorting a traveller.
